Expectation1: Follow traffic laws and drive defensively
Situation1: A school zone with children near the curb appears just as a construction detour narrows the lanes
Expectation2: Attend weekly church services to worship and participate in community activities
Situation2: They are expected to attend every service and take part in church community activities consistently
Story: I glanced at the dashboard clock—ten minutes until the church service started. I’d promised Pastor Lee I’d help set up chairs today, and I could already imagine the disappointed looks if I didn’t show. But as I turned onto Maple Avenue, the road narrowed sharply, orange cones forcing all traffic into a single lane. Up ahead, the blinking yellow lights of the school zone flashed, and a group of children clustered near the curb, waiting for the crossing guard. My phone buzzed with a reminder: “Church service, 9:00 AM.” I felt the pressure mounting. As a taxi driver, I knew I had to slow down, obey the speed limit, and watch for any sudden movement from the kids. But the minutes ticked by, and I pictured the church filling up without me, my absence noticed. My hands tightened on the wheel. I wanted to be a responsible driver, but I also wanted to be a faithful member of my church community. The weight of both expectations pressed on me, and I found myself caught between the demands of the road and the call of my faith, unsure which to answer first.
